top_comment.text:
If you seen the Lego Movie in a different perspective.. It's about people 
living in a communist society who are told what to think and to follow 
instructions.. Similar with how we are living in society today.. We aren't 
allowed to be creative, to use our own imagination to express individuality 
that makes us who we are.﻿

comments.text:
+Adrian Dickson Ever heard of a joke? lol
It's called sarcasm I believe...maybe you should look into it...
Also try not to read too much into a kids toy movie or ya know talk about 
how you see the real deeper meaning of stuff especially when you've never 
actually seen or experienced it...except maybe in kids movies, cartoons and 
comedies...lol
communism was and is oppressive, it caused great adversity, so I'm 
told...do you SAVVY? the people who endured it and those who still do are 
made to conform, they're spied on and told what to think...right? so 
naturally I thought it would be amusing to reflect that...to give ya a 
little taste so to speak...
But hey it's cool you wanna see reds under the beds or assign deep social 
and philosophical meaning to a lego movie...that's fine with me, I'm just 
fucking with strangers on the internet for my own amusement lol ya know 
because I'm "free" to be creative and use my time and imagination to annoy 
whoever I want...lol
peace
comments.author: Shamelesscritique1

were discussing the message of a freaking children's movie. Calmly. You are

you had seen the movie, you would have known what we were talking about. If 
you already have, then you're just stupid as shit. Also, who the fuck was

then your dumbass comes in. Just go. Go somewhere. Try not to crash your

comments.text: +Papa Woody Use replies like so; then we can know who you are talking to.
comments.author: SIMPalaxy

comments.text: You're a fucking idiot, bro.
comments.author: Papa Woody

comments.text:
As far as the "turn" goes, I would view it as an allegory.

After walking out of the theater, I won't lie, I had the same ideas as 
Alonso, but I went home and thought it over.

The story could have been the same without it, and the movie could have 
been great, but then they added that section in, and it created an allegory 
for the entire movie, making it unforgettably amazing.

Also, without the part, where Lord Business does what he does at the end of 
the movie, would have been incredibly anti-climatic; thus ruining the whole 
movie's goodness.
comments.author: SIMPalaxy

top_comment.text:

combined with the 3D effects that gave me headache.   I'll definitely watch

comments.author: Andrew Birbeck

comments.text:
I loved the movie. It had great jokes and a heart to it that was quite 
unexpected. It certainly is a film that everyone can watch and take 
something away from. It was one big nostalgia trip for me.

comments.text: You can't disagree. You can argue that it was not your experience though.

comments.text:

pretty empty, but there was a dad there with his two kids.  When the 
credits finally rolled, those two kids did not look happy.  And neither was 
I.  This movie is nothing compared to Lilo and Stitch, Wreck It Ralph, or 
Despicable Me.

comments.text:
As far as the "turn" goes, I would view it as an allegory.

After walking out of the theater, I won't lie, I had the same ideas as 
Alonso, but I went home and thought it over.

The story could have been the same without it, and the movie could have 
been great, but then they added that section in, and it created an allegory 
for the entire movie, making it unforgettably amazing.

Also, without the part, where Lord Business does what he does at the end of 
the movie, would have been incredibly anti-climatic; thus ruining the whole 
movie's goodness.

It's a beautiful and colorful film with great characters, funny jokes, and 
a heart to it that is quite unexpected. It's a great film and deserves all 
the praise it's getting.
comments.author: BlueHooloovoo

comments.text:
+Bluenuhvok765 I personally believe the "animation" feel made it more true 
to the imagination of a child playing with legos, no person plays with them 
seeing the whole thing smooth and seamless.
comments.author: SIMPalaxy

comments.text:
+Sighphi Yes, because wearing glasses TOTALLY determines whether or not 
somebody could see things as choppy or smooth. In that case, I could argue 
that the only reason you could see those movies being "smoother" than this 
movie is because you're wearing glasses, since glasses improve your vision.

I could also argue that since this movie isn't technically stop-motion, 
it's by default smoother than everything I've stated, but after comparing 
trailers for the aforementioned movies and this one, it looks extremely 
close to actual stop-motion movies. Hell, they even got the people at 
Aardman to work on this film with them in order to make sure it feels just 
right.
comments.author: Bluenuhvok765

comments.text:
+Bluenuhvok765
From what the trailers show this thing is nowhere near close to the level 
of most of the things you mentioned. Robot Chicken some times goes mega 
choppy but the rest do not to the degree the trailers for this movie show.

If you think the choppiness is one the same level maybe they should have 
used the pieces they used for the trailers cause those were bad or i just 
must have better vision because if you think this is on the same level as a 
Wallace and Gromit whooooo you must wear glasses.
comments.author: Sighphi

comments.text:
+Sighphi Robot Chicken is "choppy" just like this as well. So is Coraline, 
and pretty much any Tim Burton film. Wallace and Gromit and Flushed Away as 
well.
Don't try to judge it by saying it's been cutting off frames for their 
style. The entire movie is as fluid as all the movie's I've stated, and 
whatever times that the animation IS admittedly choppy is because there's 
literally no other way to do it, like a Lego ocean or dramatic entrances 
from the bad guy. Don't let those small moments prevent you from watching 
an amazing movie.
comments.author: Bluenuhvok765

comments.text:
+Bluenuhvok765

Stop motion always tries to be as fluid as possible while this movie is 
purposely cutting frames off for their style.
comments.author: Sighphi

comments.text: So basically, ANY stop-motion movie bothers you? What's wrong with that?

comments.text:
I know that. What I'm saying is that even on the day of its wide release 
there were no reviews for it. Even movies that don't get advanced 
screenings usually have reviews come in on the day of release. The last 
time I looked at RT I didn't even see one.
comments.author: The Dashboard

comments.text:
When no critics report on a movie it's because the studio doesn't screen it 
for them. Usually it's because they know it will get bad reviews, and they 
don't want those bad reviews to impact the ticket sales.

title: The Lego Movie (Starring Chris Pratt) Movie Review
